Catalyst Peak Relative area (%) Maximum peak temperature (°C) Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (900) 1 1.96 138 2 9.01 233 3 37.43 508 4 55.52 300 Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1000) 1 1.27 139 2 5.50 235 3 63.95 311 4 29.27 535 Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1050) 1 19.99 127 2 26.22 226 3 14.95 320 4 78.81 478 Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1100) 1 13.31 114 2 37.80 238 3 48.88 497 Pd/Al2O3 (1050) 1 6.09 245 2 93.91 336 Pd/Al2O3 (1100) 1 19.31 129 2 80.69 311 The influence of alumina phases on the performance of the Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalyst in tail-end selective hydrogenation of acetylene Samane Komeili a ⁎ Maryam Takht Ravanchi b Abbas Taeb a a Chemical Engineering Department, Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran, Iran Chemical Engineering Department Iran University of Science and Technology Tehran Iran b Catalyst Research Group, Petrochemical Research and Technology Co., National Petrochemical Company, Tehran, Iran Catalyst Research Group Petrochemical Research and Technology Co. National Petrochemical Company Tehran Iran ⁎ Corresponding author at: Chemical Engineering Department, Iran University of Science and Technology, Narmak, Tehran 1311416846, Iran. Fax: +98 21 77240495. Graphical abstract A series of alumina mixing phases were prepared as catalyst supports by heating commercial γ-Al2O3 at 900°C, 1000°C, 1050°C, and 1100°C. These supports were then impregnated stepwise and calcined to prepare 0.03wt% Pd and 0.09wt% Ag catalysts. The prepared samples were characterized by XRD, BET, NH3–TPD, ZP, CO–TPD, SEM, EDS, and UV–vis DRS, and their catalytic performances were evaluated for selective hydrogenation of acetylene. The phase transformation route of alumina was in: γ→(γ+δ+θ) (900°C)→(δ+θ) (1000°C)→(δ+θ) (1050°C)→(α) (1100°C). By increasing the heating temperature between 900°C and 1100°C, the surface area decreased from 244m2/g to 16.4m2/g, the number of acidic sites was decreased, especially for strong acid sites. The acetylene conversion of Pd/Al2O3 was between 15 and 80% and the best one was for the alumina heated at 1050°C. Ag shaped the strong adsorption multi-coordination sites and lowered the strength of adsorption linear active sites. Keywords Pd–Ag/Al2O3 Selective hydrogenation Acetylene Alumina phase 1 Introduction A trace amount of acetylene acts as a permanent poison for the ethylene polymerization catalyst. The selective hydrogenation of acetylene to produce ethylene is the most economical route for acetylene removal [1–3]. The feed and operation conditions of selective hydrogenation of acetylene reactor are categorized in two configurations: “front-end” or “tail-end”. The main difference between them is amount of hydrogen in the feed. Front-end acetylene hydrogenation units are run at much higher partial pressures of hydrogen but tail-end acetylene hydrogenation units, however, typically operate at much lower partial pressures of hydrogen [4]. An alumina-supported palladium catalyst with a silver promoter is the most common catalyst for this selective hydrogenation [1,5,6]. Alumina exists in several transition forms and structures, including γ, η, β, χ, κ, δ, θ, and α, while α-alumina is the most stable phase thermodynamically and usually crystallizes at high temperatures [1]. The nature of alumina phases have been very poorly understood in catalysis because of their lower crystallinity [7]. Catalytic performance of alumina supports depends upon the alumina structure, and its active site interactions may be considered in terms of adsorption strength, particle charging and sizes, formation of multi-functional active sites, changes in particle morphology, and dispersion of active sites [2,8–10]. It has been reported that increasing the amount of α phase in the mixture of θ and γ aluminas causes both Pd dispersion and the number of active sites to decrease and particle sizes to increase. The catalytic performance in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene on the mixture of α, θ, and γ-Al2O3 was better than pure α-Al2O3 support [1]. It has also been reported that silver nanoparticles were shaped sizes less than 5nm on the η-alumina phase, 10–20nm on the α-alumina phase, and higher than 20nm on the δ-alumina phase [11]. Acetylene and ethylene are associatively and dissociatively adsorbed on Pd in di-σ, π, ethylidene, vinyl, ethylidyne, and vinylidene configurations [12,4]. The formation of each transient intermediate is important in elucidating the controlling reaction paths [13]. The intermolecular competition for adsorption at each site may be different [12]. It is proposed that a multiply bonded surface such as ethylidene, ethylidyne, and vinylidene participated in forming oligomers. It is also possible that C–C bonds might be formed though a recombination of neighboring intermediates or by inserting a C2 unit on an existing Pd–C bond [14]. Most of the studies confirmed that adsorption of acetylene in the form of a π and di-σ bond and vinyl species on the high-dispersed Pd (lower particle size) were the key parameters needed to obtain high activity and selectivity [12,4,14,15]. A series of narrow adsorption sites able to adsorb acetylene and hydrogen, but unable adsorb ethylene, were favored to adsorb acetylene and are therefore inactive for ethylene hydrogenation. Ethylene adsorbed most favorably in the π and di-σ adsorption modes, but in the presence of acetylene, Pd is selecting to adsorb acetylene by thermodynamic explanations. The palladium has a much stronger adsorption of acetylene than ethylene because of differences between the heats of adsorption on palladium [4]. The purpose of this study was to investigate the role and effect of polymorph alumina phases as supports for Pd–Ag catalysts in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Commercially spherical γ-Al2O3 (BET: 210.13m2/g and pore volume: 0.53cm3/g), supplied by Sasol Co., as well as palladium chloride (PdCl2) and silver nitrate (AgNO3) purchased from Merck Co. were used as palladium and silver precursors. These precursors were graded analytically and used without further purification. Cylinders of acetylene and ethylene gas mix (containing 1.5mol%, C2H2, and C2H4 as balance), hydrogen and nitrogen (with 99.9mol% purity) were used as the reactant and diluent gases. 2.2 Catalysts preparation 2.2.1 Support Four γ-Al2O3 samples were used as feedstock and heated in an electrical furnace with 5°C/min heating rates until reaching the selected planed temperature, at which point the temperature was set to constant for three hours to prepare several alumina mixtures to be used as catalyst supports. The selected final temperatures were 900°C, 1000°C, 1050°C, and 1100°C, and they were named samples A, B, C, and D, respectively. The prepared supports were studied using XRD to determine the related phases, TPD–NH3 to determine titration of acid sites, BET and BJH to identify their textural properties, and using ZP to measure zeta potential distribution around alumina surfaces. 2.2.2 Catalysts preparation The Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared using the sequential wet impregnation method. The Pd precursor was solved in water with a pH around 1 that adjusted by chloridric acid while in contact with each support sample in the rotary at 40°C for three hours. The samples were then calcined in air at 250°C for three hours until they are approximately 0.03wt% Pd. The silver precursor was solved in water and impregnated with Pd/Al2O3 samples in the rotary for three hours at ambient temperature. The samples were then calcined in air at 450°C for three hours to reach the promoted catalyst with around 0.09wt% of Ag. The prepared catalysts were characterized using SEM, EDS, CO–TPD, UV–vis DRS, and by reaction performance. 2.3 Supports & catalysts characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Al2O3 supports were carried out using an X-ray diffractometer (Model GNRMPD 3000) with Cu-Kα radiation at 40kV and 30mA. The surface areas of the supports were determined by N2 physisorption using a BET adsorption analyzer type Quantachrome Nova 2200. The BET measurements, nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore structure analysis were conducted at 77K. The pore size distribution was determined by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The water-displacement method was used for measuring of macro pores volume [16]. For such study, dry samples were weighted and immersed in water at 70°C for 1h and then cooled to ambient temperature. The difference between the weights of a saturated sample in air and dry sample, was set as the weight of water displacement in pores and by using water density, pore volume was calculated. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) measurements of CO and NH3 were performed in BELCAT A. Ammonia adsorption was carried out at 60°C in a mixture of NH3 (2.5cc/min) and He (47.5cc/min) flows for one hour. The product was then exposed to He for 30min at 60°C to remove all the physically adsorbed species before starting the temperature program. The samples adsorbed ammonia at 60°C heated up to 700°C with a heating rate of 10°C/min. The amount of acid sites on the catalyst surface was calculated based on desorption amount of ammonia. For CO–TPD, the samples were reduced at 150°C in H2 for two hours, and purged with He at 150°C for one hour to remove adsorbed H2 from the Pd surface. The catalyst was then exposed to CO at 40°C and then the temperature was raised from 40°C to 600°C with a rate of 10°C/min. Desorption signals were monitored by using a TCD spectrometer. The CO–TPD graphs were deconvoluted by using a Gaussian model with the least square method and the results with R 2 ≥0.99 are reported here. Zeta potential measurements were performed with Nano ZS (red badge) ZEN 3600 from Malvern Inc. The suspensions were prepared using milled support dispersed in distillate water with the help of an ultrasonic device (samples had been submitted to ultrasonic waves for ten minutes in order to destroy aggregates and to gain a good dispersion). The pH of suspensions was measured. The analysis of metal penetration depth was performed in a scanning electron microscope (SEM) using VEGA II TESCAN apparatus. The cross sectional of each spherical pellet was polished and covered with Au layer and studied with a scanning electron microscope (SEM). The measurement was carried out under high vacuum by an electron beam having a voltage of 15kV. The depth of the active site layer was read out from SEM images. The amount of Pd and Ag was measured by the EDS technique at the surface and the center point of use sphere. 2.4 Reaction performance The performance of catalysts for tail-end selective hydrogenation of acetylene was tested using a high pressure reactor made of stainless steel (SS316) that has an internal diameter of 14.5mm and wall thickness of 1.5mm. A thermocouple was placed in the centre of the reactor tube. The temperature of the reactor was adjusted by a heating jacket. The catalyst was reduced in situ with hydrogen (GHSV of 500h−1) for 4h at 150°C. Then the reactor was purged with nitrogen and cooled down to the reaction temperature (60°C). A mixture of acetylene, ethylene and hydrogen with 1:60:1.5mol% and nitrogen as balance at GHSV of 5760h−1 were introduced through mass flow controllers (BROOKS instrument series 5866). The reaction pressure was kept at 10bar by a back pressure regulator (BROOKS instrument SLA 5850). The feed and products were analyzed by an on-line gas chromatograph (Thermoquest, Trace 2000). The absence of heat and mass transfer limitations were approved for this process at operating conditions of the present research (the interested reader is referred to Appendix A for further details). Acetylene conversion (Eq. (1)) and ethylene selectivity (Eq. (2)) were used to evaluate the performance of the catalyst. (1) Acetylene conversion = ( C 2 H 2 ) in − ( C 2 H 2 ) out ( C 2 H 2 ) in × 100 (2) Ethylene selectivity = ( C 2 H 2 ) in − ( C 2 H 2 ) out − ( C 2 H 6 ) produced − 2 ( C 4 H 8 ) produced ( C 2 H 2 ) in − ( C 2 H 2 ) out × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Support 3.1.1 XRD The XRD patterns of the prepared alumina supports are shown in Fig. 1 . The mixture of the transition aluminas (γ, δ, and θ) was obtained at 900°C (sample A) (Fig. 1(a)), and in one case, a temperature of 1000°C (sample B), while the dominant phases were θ and δ aluminas (Fig. 1(b)).At 1050°C (sample C), two transition aluminas, δ and θ, were formed (Fig. 1(c)), and the peaks assigned to the θ alumina were considered growth because the amount of θ alumina in this sample was more than in sample B. As seen in (Fig. 1(d)), and according to ICDD file no. 46-1212, nine sharp peaks confirmed the alpha phase was formed at 1100°C. In Table 1 , the alumina phases that were observed in each sample are shown. From XRD can be concluded that the phase transformation route of alumina by temperature changing was in: γ→(γ+δ+θ) (900°C)→(δ+θ) (1000°C)→(δ+θ) (1050°C)→(α) (1100°C) 3.1.2 BET & BJH As shown in Table 1, the specific surface areas, determined using the BET method, decreased with increasing temperature, which is attributable to the structural changes of the alumina and the destruction of some small pores. Compared to the samples heated at 900–1100°C, the surface area decreased quickly from 244m2/g to 16.4m2/g. The mean pore sizes, calculated using the BJH method, were around 8.9nm in the mesopore range, according to IUPAC classification. For the samples heated at 900–1050°C, the pore structure of samples collapsed when the temperature was increased from 1050°C to 1100°C. The specific pore volume decreased from 0.53cc/g to 0.356cc/g by increasing temperatures. 3.1.3 NH3–TPD NH3–TPD data from the prepared supports at different heating temperatures are shown in Table 2 . The presence of two acid site types (strong and weak) on these supports was reported. By increasing the heating temperature, the number of acidic sites was decreased, and rather drastically so in the case of strong acid sites. The amount of desorbed ammonia per alumina mass represents the concentration of acid sites. These samples contained stronger acid site types than weak site types, but the strength of the acidic sites (temperature at maximum of peaks) did not change significantly during phase changing. Following the Lewis acid definition, it is clear that by increasing the heating temperature, the number of acceptable electron pairs will decrease, which has an influence on the interaction of Pd and Ag with these supports and this may reduce the number of active sites with tendencies toward high adsorption strength. In researching [14], the coke deposition on the catalyst is attributable to the acidic properties of the support resulting from the high interaction between carbon species. Fewer acid sites may be suitable for the Pd–alumina catalyst in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene. The low adsorption strength of active sites reduces coke deposition and prevents deep hydrogenation to ethane. 3.1.4 Zeta potential The nature of the supports is one of the main parameters that affects the interaction between the support surface and the active site precursor solution. It can be interpreted using the following mechanisms: (1) electrostatic interaction, (2) ion-exchange, and (3) ligand-exchange [17]. The electrostatic interaction depends upon the support charge and pH of the precursor. Zeta potential measurements have provided useful information regarding the support charge in catalyst preparations [18]. The zeta potential of the support was measured while in contact with water at pH 6–7 to view the distribution of surface charges. Zeta potential distribution of supports is shown in Fig. 2 . For sample A, three peaks were reported (Fig. 2(a)). The average zeta potential and related area percentage of each peak are shown in Table 2. For sample A (900 °C), approximately 33.8% of the zeta layer around surface has a −6.77mV potential, 61.4% has a −27.7mV potential, and 4.4% has positive electrical potential. These differences may be related to the presence of different structures of alumina (γ, δ, and θ) in this sample. The difference between the potential surface charges shows that the adsorption of palladium and silver precursor species are non-uniform. For sample C, the two peaks are indicated (Fig. 2(b) and Table 2). Approximately 40.1% of the zeta layer around the surface has −49mV zeta potential, and approximately 59.9% of the surface has −14mV zeta potential. By increasing the electrostatic attraction between the metal complex in an impregnating solution, the support leads to smaller metal particles [18]. Additionally, Pd complex adsorption in the precursor may have uniform distribution on the surface of support C compared to support A. For sample D, two peaks were indicated near each other (Fig. 2(c)). As was shown in Table 2, 59.7% of the zeta layer has approximately −14mV, and 40.3% has approximately −24.1mV zeta potential. By alumina phase changing from γ to δ, θ and α, zeta potential distribution of surfaces was varied. The quantity of metallic precursor that can be adsorb by the supports depends on the value of the surface charge of the support [19]. So the different quantity adsorption of Pd complex leaded to form different Pd active sites on the prepared supports. 3.2 Catalysts Monometallic Pd/Al2O3 catalysts prepared by impregnation were identified as Pd/Al2O3 (900), Pd/Al2O3 (1000), Pd/Al2O3 (1050), and Pd/Al2O3 (1100), and the promoted catalysts were named Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (900), Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1000), Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1050), and Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1100). Digits in parentheses indicate the heating temperatures of the alumina support. 3.2.1 UV–vis DRS Diffusive reflectance UV–vis spectra of Pd/Al2O3 and Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalysts of A, C, and D supports are shown in Fig. 3 . For Pd/Al2O3 catalysts, two main absorption bands at 204–298nm and 400–487nm can be attributed to the charge transfer bands and d–d transitions, respectively. The bands at 483 or 490 can be ascribed to bulk PdO particles that have a low level of interaction with the support [20,21]. For the Ag/Al2O3 catalysts, the peaks at 210, 260nm are generally attributed to highly dispersed Ag+ cations. A peak at 350nm is assigned to oxidized silver clusters (Ag m+), and a peak at 420nm is linked to Ag0 [22–24]. For catalysts on support A, the lower graph (Pd/Al2O3 (900)) has bands at 224, 272, and 542nm, but the upper graph (Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (900)) has bands at 220, 258, and 426nm, and a weak band at 360nm. Silver was changed in the band which resulted in the shifted the bands to lower wavelengths. The band at 360nm was linked to Ag m+ clusters. This new peak was expected because the amount of silver contained was around three times greater than the amount of palladium. Bands were seen for the catalysts on support C for Pd/Al2O3 (1050) at 226, 270, and 540nm, and for Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1050), bands were seen at 210, 258, 350, and 500nm. The bands at 210nm were assigned to bands of pure Ag+ on the alumina and 350nm for the Ag m+ clusters. Adding Ag to the sample bands at 226 and 270nm caused these bands to disappear, and new bands were formed at 258nm. For catalysts on support D, the bands at 294 and 548nm shifted to 258 and 506nm and only the weak band related to Ag m+ clusters at 356nm were added. By adding Ag to the Pd/Al2O3 catalysts, the growth of the absorption band intensity and a shift of peak positions to lower wavelengths were observed (Fig. 3), because silver promotes the electronic bands and interacts with Pd ions on the catalysts. Changing the Pd/Al2O3 spectra with silver is related to the bimetallic Pd–Ag particle formation and the variation in the first Pd interactions. Some Ag atoms dissolved in the palladium lattice, thereby altered its electronic properties. 3.2.2 SEM & EDS Cross-sectional SEM images of each promoted catalyst are shown in Fig. 4 . The brighter region is related to heavy elements of backscatter electrons, which are used to detect the contrast between areas with different chemical compositions [25]. For sample Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (900), a very narrow shell was observed (Fig. 3(a)). The Pd and Ag particles were very close together, and were aggregated. One of parameters can effect on this various particle sizes related to non-uniform distribution of surface charge potential of support A during adsorption of Pd and Ag complexes in impregnation. It could have an unfavorable performance in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene and the catalyst may be deactivated very soon. The high adsorption power of support A, due to presence of γ-alumina, was caused by palladium and silver adsorption on the surface of the support with a high degree of aggregation. The eggshell thickness of sample Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1000) was larger (around 145μm) than others and very tiny Pd–Ag particles were observed in a bright point in Fig. 4(b). The particles were very close together. Interaction between Pd and Ag with the δ and θ alumina did not produced large particles like the γ, δ, and θ alumina mixing phases support (sample A). For sample Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1050), the eggshell thickness was around 80μm. The spacing of the tiny bright point in Fig. 4(c) (Pd and Ag particles) was set further apart compared to sample Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1000), due to increase amount of θ-alumina on the support C. For Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1100), the shell layer was thinner and around 20μm. No bright point was seen in Fig. 4(d) due to very small particles. It is possible that Pd–Ag were nanoparticles in this instance. These egg shell dispersion patterns were related to a tendency toward adsorption of different alumina phases due to their surface electron density, structure, and surface area. In Table 3 , the amount of palladium and silver on the surface of the catalyst, as well as the center, which was measured using EDS, are shown. This point measurement indicated that the accumulation of Pd particles in samples Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1000) and Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (900) were higher than in the others. The difference between them was the size of the particles. Sample Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (900), for instance, had large particles with low dispersion, but in sample Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1000), very tiny particles near one another were shaped. Neither was suitable for the catalyst performance in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene. In samples Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1050) and Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1100), the local amount of Pd was lower in the order than in other samples. For all samples, the Pd and Ag point concentration were different as was expected from impregnation method. 3.2.3 Reaction performance The interactions between palladium and different structures of alumina were created at different active sites in particle sizes, coordination, distribution, and distances between particles and interaction with support. The performance of Pd/Al2O3 catalysts in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene is shown in Fig. 5 (a). For sample Pd/Al2O3 (900), acetylene conversion was low (around 15%), which means that this catalyst had low activity. Higher support acidity than other supports promoted the adsorption strength of active sites. As seen in the SEM images (Fig. 4(a)), large Pd–Ag particles near each other led to unfavorable active sites that soon deactivated catalyst. The hydrocarbons were settled or dissolved in the large Pd particles. Sample Pd/Al2O3 (1000) had lower acidity sites (Table 2) and smaller particles (Fig. 4(b)) compared to Pd/Al2O3 (900). As shown in Fig. 5(a) for sample Pd/Al2O3 (1000), the acetylene conversion was around 70%, but ethylene selectivity was decreased to around 50% after 11h. The adsorbed acetylene or intermediates species were reacted together and ethylene selectivity was dropped because the Pd active sites in close proximity may be the cause of neighboring phenomena The best rates of acetylene conversion (80%) and ethylene selectivity (70%) were gained in sample Pd/Al2O3 (1050) (Fig. 5(a)). Palladium active sites were discovered to be the best sites for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene and the thin eggshell layer of active sites. Higher amounts of selectivity than those found in sample Pd/Al2O3 (1000) were related to the increasing amount of θ alumina phase in the support and were caused to limit oligomerization of adsorbed intermediate. In sample Pd/Al2O3 (1100), the Pd on the alpha alumina structure, acetylene conversion was around 55%, and ethylene selectivity soon dropped to around 40% after 11h. Low surface area and very low acidity, along with a higher surface electron potential of the supports decreased the adsorption strength of active sites. For Pd/Al2O3 (1100), a slightly higher electron surface potential of support may promote electron density of Pd and decreased electron strength of active sites. The catalyst performance by the Ag addition as a promoter is shown in Fig. 5(b). Ag decreased the activity of Pd/Al2O3, but enhanced ethylene selectivity by decreasing the quantity of hydrogen absorbed and reducing its rate of diffusion from the bulk of active sites to the surface [16]. Ag particles block some active sites and change their coordination. There were few active sites that participated in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene, so the activity was lowered, but ethylene selectivity was raised and stable during the 11h on the stream. The effect of Ag addition on Pd/Al2O3 (1100) was more favorable than on the other samples. The strength and coordination of active sites could be considered using the CO–TPD method, as seen in the next section. 3.2.4 CO–TPD Monometallic Pd/Al2O3 and promoted Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalysts were studied by temperature programmed desorption using CO as the probe molecules. CO can adsorb on on-top sites (linear CO), bridges, and 3-fold hollow sites (multiply bonded CO) with different adsorption energies. This phenomenon can analyze the distribution and strength of adsorption sites accessible for CO on Pd active sites [26,27]. The low temperature peak was attributed to the desorption of CO bound in lower coordination sites (the on-top sites) and the high-temperature peak was assigned to the desorption of CO bound to multi-coordination sites, so the interaction of CO with the active site of catalysts was represented on Pd coordination sites [26–29]. The relative area percentage and the maximum temperature of the peaks are shown in Table 4 . The relative area percentage was the ratio of the area under the peak per total area of convoluted peak and corresponded to the number of related Pd sites. Fig. 6 (a) shows the CO–TPD graph of Pd/Al2O3 (1050), which had the best performance in the catalytic reactor. It had two peaks. The relative area percentage of peaks 1 and 2 were 6.09% and 93.91%, respectively, as shown in Table 4. The numbers of Pd sites related to peak 2 were much greater than peak 1 so the interaction of δ and θ alumina by Pd, obtained one kind of Pd sites related to peak 2, approximately. There was a proper distance between Pd active sites in sample Pd/Al2O3 (1050), so the intermediate species did not react with each other and selectivity was acceptable. The maximum temperature of the peaks was 245°C and 336°C, respectively, which confirmed the high adsorption strength of active site. For sample Pd/Al2O3 (1100), two peaks were identified. The number of sites related to peak 1 was increased compared to Pd/Al2O3 (1050). The relative area of peak 1was approximately 19.3%, and peak 2 was approximately 80.69%. The maximum temperature of peak 1 was around 130°C and 311°C for peak 2 (Table 4). This showed that the adsorption strength of active sites was lower than Pd/Al2O3 (1050), so the activity was decreased. The structure of alpha alumina with higher surface electron potential was the promoted electron density of active sites. In NH3–TPD, it was concluded that the number of acid sites of alumina decreased by increasing heating temperature (Table 2). Thus, the adsorption strength of Pd active sites on the surface of alumina was decreased by decreasing the number of acid sites. By adding Ag as a promoter to the catalysts, the adsorption strength of primary Pd active sites was decreased (Table 4). For example, the first peak of Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1050) shifted by 118°C less than Pd/Al2O3 (1050). This alloying increased the types of Pd active sites. By adding Ag to sample Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1050), for instance, two new types of adsorption sites were observed. These sites had higher adsorption intensity with CO in multi-coordination configuration. The second peak of Fig. 7 (a) was divided into three peaks (Fig. 7(c)). In sample Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1100), three peaks were observed in CO–TPD (Fig. 7(d)). The first one decreased in temperature by 15°C. The relative area of peak 1 was around 20%, and around 13.3% for Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1050) and Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1100), respectively. This showed that Ag shaped the strong adsorption multi-coordination sites very closely to sites that corresponded to deactivate infinity and did not participate in acetylene hydrogenation; thus, the activity was decreased and the ethylene selectivity was improved as a result of Ag lowering the strength of adsorption linear active sites. For sample Pd/Al2O3 (900) and Pd/Al2O3 (1000), unpromoted Pd catalysts had an unfavorable performance in the acetylene hydrogenation only on Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (900), Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1000) was characterized with CO–TPD (Fig. 7(a and b)). The interaction of Pd on these supports led to the oligomerization of deposited hydrocarbon species. Significant Pd sites (around 97%, Table 4) correspond to peaks 3 and 4, sites with strong adsorption strength and multi-coordination [30]. 4 Conclusion Different transition aluminas shaped different active sites in size, coordination, adsorption strength. These were related to their structures, which produce different electrostatic interaction and acidity. The strength of active sites was reduced by decreasing the amount of support acidity. Ag deposition using wet impregnation blocked Pd active sites and decreased the adsorption strength of active sites, which led to favorable performance. Unfavorable events, due to Ag deposition, were the basis for the formation of very strong active sites that soon deactivated. Appendix A If the heat transfer resistance of the wall is negligible compared with that for radial transfer through the bed, the following criterion is applicable [31]: (A.1) | Δ H | r b R 0 2 k e T w < 0.4 R T w E where | Δ H | is the absolute value of the heat of reaction (J/mol), r b observed reaction rate per unit volume of bed (mol/m3 h), R 0 radius of the reactor (m), k e effective bed thermal conductivity (W/mK), T w temperature of the wall (K), R gas constant (J/molK) and E is activation energy (J/mol). In smaller laboratory reactors, heat transfer resistance at the reactor wall is significant and under these circumstances the criterion must be made more stringent by reducing the right hand side of the inequality by a factor of about 2. Effective thermal conductivity, k e, of a packed bed of catalyst particles may be thought of as consisting of a stagnant conductive and a conductivity arising from flow through the bed. The following relationship is used to correlate k e [31]. (A.2) k e k g = k e 0 k g + R e p P r Ć where k e 0 is stagnant thermal conductivity of the bed (W/mK), k g thermal conductivity of the fluid (W/mK), Re p particle Reylonds number, Pr fluid Prandtl number and Ć is a constant. For determining k e 0 , Kunii and Smith model [32] leads to below expression: (A.3) k e 0 k g = e + β ( 1 − e ) ϕ + γ ( k g / k s ) where e is bed porosity, β and γ geometric factors, ϕ dimensionless gas film resistance and k s is the thermal conductivity of catalyst pellet (W/mK). A value of 1 is suggested for β, γ =2/3, Ć =10 and ϕ can be obtained from a graphical representation given in Ref. [32]. In the case of the acetylene selective hydrogenation process discussed in the present research, the exothermic heat of reaction for Eq. (1) is −172kJ/mol. The observed reaction rate is expressed as rate per unit volume of bed that would be 2.3×10−7 mol/cm3 s for sample Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1100), for instance. From literature [33], the activation energy is 40kJ/mol. Thus for Eq. (A.1): LHS = 172 × 10 3 × 2.3 × 10 − 7 × ( 1.45 / 2 ) 2 2.5 × 10 − 2 × 333 = 0.0025 RHS = 0.4 × 8.314 × 333 2 × 40 × 10 3 = 0.014 Apparently, the radial temperature gradient was not significant and reaction bed was isotherm. For calculating effective thermal conductivity using Eq. (A.2), a value of k s =3600W/mK is used on the basis of literature [34]. Thermal conductivity of feed gas at reaction condition is 3.9×10−2 W/mK. Taking the porosity of the bed as about 0.5 and a value of 0.008 for ϕ [32], Eq. (A.2) would be: k e k g = k e 0 k g + R e p P r Ć = e + β ( 1 − e ) ϕ + γ ( k g / k s ) + R e p P r Ć = 0.5 + 0.5 0.008 + 2 / 3 ( 3.9 × 10 − 2 / 3600 ) + 23.05 × 0.49 10 = 64.07 ⇒ k e = 64.07 × 3.9 × 10 − 2 = 2.5 W / m K The Weisz–Prater criterion (Eq. (A.4)) is used to determine if internal diffusion is limiting the reaction or not [35]. (A.4) C WP = r b ′ ρ c R p 2 D e C AS where C WP is Weisz–Prater criterion, r b ′ observed reaction rate per catalyst weight (mol/kgh), ρ c bulk density of catalyst bed (kg/m3), R p catalyst particle radius (m), D e is effective diffusivity (m2/h) and C AS is acetylene concentration at the catalyst surface (mol/m3). If C WP <1, there are no diffusion limitations and consequently no concentration gradient exists within the pellet. If C WP >1, internal diffusion limits the reaction severely. In the acetylene selective hydrogenation process of the present research and for sample Pd–Ag/Al2O3 (1100), for instance, the observed reaction rate would be 2.67×10−7 mol/gs and effective diffusivity of the feed gas mixture was 1.71×10−3 cm2/s. Hence, Eq. (A.4) would be: C WP = 2.67 × 10 − 7 × 0.9 × ( 1.5 / 2 × 10 ) 2 1.71 × 10 − 3 × 3.9 × 10 − 6 = 0.2 As C WP is less than unity, there were no significant diffusion limitations and no concentration gradient to exist within the catalyst particle. coredata.dc:description: A series of alumina mixing phases were prepared as catalyst supports by heating commercial γ-Al2O3 at 900°C, 1000°C, 1050°C, and 1100°C. These supports were then impregnated stepwise and calcined to prepare 0.03wt% Pd and 0.09wt% Ag catalysts. The prepared samples were characterized by XRD, BET, NH3–TPD, ZP, CO–TPD, SEM, EDS, and UV–vis DRS, and their catalytic performances were evaluated for selective hydrogenation of acetylene. The phase transformation route of alumina was in: γ→(γ+δ+θ) (900°C)→(δ+θ) (1000°C)→(δ+θ) (1050°C)→(α) (1100°C). By increasing the heating temperature between 900°C and 1100°C, the surface area decreased from 244m2/g to 16.4m2/g, the number of acidic sites was decreased, especially for strong acid sites. The acetylene conversion of Pd/Al2O3 was between 15 and 80% and the best one was for the alumina heated at 1050°C. Ag shaped the strong adsorption multi-coordination sites and lowered the strength of adsorption linear active sites.
coredata.dc:title: The influence of alumina phases on the performance of the Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalyst in tail-end selective hydrogenation of acetylene
